verses.verse: When they were safe, they found out that the island was named Malta.
The natives showed us the type of kindness not seen every day, for they lit a fire and welcomed everyone of us, because it was raining and cold.
Paul had gathered a bunch of sticks and laid them on the fire, then a poisonous snake came out because of the heat and clamped down on his hand.

When the natives saw the poisonous snake hanging on his hand, they said among themselves, "No doubt, this man is a murderer, and even though he has escaped the sea, justice will not allow him to live."
Then he shook off the creature into the fire and was not harmed at all.

Nevertheless they were waiting when he should swell up or suddenly fall down dead, but after they had watched for a long time and saw no harm happen to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
In that same area were the lands of Publius, the chief of the island, who welcomed us and kindly lodged us for three days.
It then happened that Publius' father was lying sick from a fever and dysentery. Paul went in and prayed, laid hands on him, and healed him.
So after this was done, others who also were sick on the island came and were healed.
Who also honored us with many types of gifts, and when we left, they gave us all what we needed.
After three months, we left in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered at the island, whose sign was "The Twin Gods,"
and landing at Syracuse, we stayed there three days.
From there we sailed along and came to Rhegium, and after one day the south wind blew, and we arrived the day following at Puteoli.
Where we found brethren and were invited to stay with them for seven days. After that we moved toward Rome.
From there when the brethren heard about us, they came to meet us as far as the market of Appii and the Three Taverns. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and was encouraged.
When we came to Rome, the centurion handed the prisoners to the captain of the guard, but Paul was allowed to live by himself with a soldier that guarded him.

Then it came about that three days later Paul called for the chief of the Jews to come together, and when they were together, he said to them, "Men and brethren, though I have done nothing wrong against the People or the customs of our forefathers, yet I was handed over as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
"Who when they had examined me would have let me go, because there was no crime in me [deserving] the death penalty.
"But when the Jews spoke against it, it was necessary to appeal to Caesar, even though I had nothing for which to accuse my nation.
"For this reason, therefore, I have called for you, to see you and to speak with you, because for the hope of Israel, I am bound with these chains."
They said to him, "We have not received letters from Judea about you, nor have any of the brethren that came reported or told us of any evil about you.
"But we want to hear from you, what you think, for concerning this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere."

When they had appointed a time for him, many came to him where he was staying. He talked in detail to them and testified about the Kingdom of God, persuading them about Jesus, both from the Law of Moses and the Prophets from morning to night.
Some believed the things that he talked about, but others did not believe.
When they could not agree among themselves, they left after Paul spoke one more thing, "The Holy Spirit said it well through Isaiah the prophet to our forefathers,
saying, «Go to this people and say, "You will hear it and hear it but not understand, and you will look at it and look at it but not comprehend it.

«For the heart of this people is calloused, and their ears are dull of hearing. They have closed their eyes, lest they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart, and then be converted, and I would heal them.»
"Be it known, therefore, by you that the salvation of God is sent out to the Gentiles, and they will hear it."
After saying these words, the Jews left and had a great discussion [about this] among themselves.
Paul lived for two whole years in his own rented house and welcomed all who came to him,
preaching the Kingdom of God and teaching things about the Lord Jesus Christ boldly, no one stopping him.
